reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: I don’t understand the deep economics of streaming and content production the way I understand Coca-Cola syrup or insurance premiums. Netflix sits well outside my circle, and I’m reminded that "Risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing."
2. Competitive Moat: While Netflix has a recognizable brand and a library of content, the metrics show only 1 out of 10 periods with ROE over 15% and inconsistent earnings growth. A 70% performance stability hints at some footing, but it’s no fortress. Content costs are rising, and competitors like Disney+ and Amazon Prime are nipping at its heels.
3. Management & Capital Allocation: Management has plowed billions into content, piling debt up at a 1.34 debt-to-equity ratio and generating negative owner earnings of $164 million. No dividends, no significant share buybacks—just more borrowing. That kind of capital deployment doesn’t inspire confidence.
4. Financial Health & Consistency: ROE of 0.3%, return on invested capital of 0.1%, and a 93% drop in earnings over ten periods point to volatility. High operating margins are nice, but they haven’t translated into durable profits or positive free cash flow.
5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: The three-stage DCF delivers a negative intrinsic value around ‑$1,300 per share, and a margin of safety of ‑101%. You pay more than the business is worth. I never buy a fair business at a wonderful price.
6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: Streaming is a frenetic business with constant content churn, rising production costs, and fierce competition. Debt load will pressure the bottom line when interest rates rise. I don’t see a durable tailwind that lasts for decades.
7. Portfolio Comparison: I’d rather own See’s Candies, Coca-Cola, or even Apple—as a consumer ecosystem business—than take a flyer on Netflix. When in doubt, I say no. There’s no penalty for passing on this.
Conclusion: NFLX sits outside my circle, lacks a proven moat, carries worrisome debt, and trades above any sensible value. My verdict is a bearish signal.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 0.3%; High debt to equity ratio of 1.3; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -93.0% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 41.0%) suggest some competitive advantage; High performance stability (70.3%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-3.5%, 5y), Stage 2 (-1.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
